intro: Quercus felipensis, commonly known as the Mexican white oak, is a deciduous tree native to the mountainous regions of Mexico. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its lobed leaves and acorns. The tree typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has a broad, rounded crown. Its bark is usually smooth and grayish, with a rough texture as it matures. Quercus felipensis plays an important role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
